tn.ref: She has not listened to the voice of God
tn.text: The people of Jerusalem have not obeyed what God has had His prophets teach to them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and will not approach her God
tn.text: The people do not desire to worship and obey God.

tn.ref: Her princes are roaring lions in her midst
tn.text: AT: "Jerusalem's leaders are violent." (See: [[ en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Her judges are evening wolves who leave nothing to be gnawed upon in the morning
tn.text: AT: "Her judges are evil people who take things that belong to others." This is also a metaphor.

tn.ref: Her prophets are insolent and treasonous men
tn.text: AT: "Her prophets are disobedient and disloyal men."

tn.ref: It will not be hidden in the light
tn.text: AT: "his justice is clearly shown to all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: I have made their streets ruins, so that no one passes over them. Their cities are destroyed so that there is no man inhabiting them
tn.text: Yahweh expresses the same idea in two different ways in order to emphasize the complete destruction of the cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Yahweh's declaration
tn.text: This means what Yahweh has solemnly said.

tn.ref: I rise up for the victim
tn.text: "I rise up to destroy the victim"

tn.ref: to gather the nations, to assemble the kingdoms
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will judge all of the nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: my anger, all my fierce wrath
tn.text: The words "anger" and "fierce wrath" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of Yahweh's anger. AT: "my very fierce wrath." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: so that all the land will be devoured by the fire of my anger
tn.text: This phrase can be expressed in active form. AT: "so that the fire of my anger will devour all the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: devoured by the fire of my anger
tn.text: Anger is here spoken of as if it were fire that could devour something. (See: [[: en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will give pure lips to the people
tn.text: This is another way of saying that God will cause his people to speak what is right. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: serve me standing shoulder to shoulder
tn.text: The people will be united in their desire to serve God, as people are united physically when they stand together with their shoulders touching each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: no deceitful tongue will be found in their mouth
tn.text: AT: "no one will find a deceitful tongue in their mouth" or "they will not say deceitful things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they will graze and lie down
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel as if they are a flock of sheep that grazes and rests in safety. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: daughter of Zion
tn.text: "This means all the people in Jerusalem.

tn.ref: Do not let your hands falter
tn.text: This means do not feel weak or helpless as you would if your hands became physically weak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will rescue the lame and gather up the outcast
tn.text: This appears to refer to lame and outcast sheep, which serve as an image of the Israelites who suffered in exile. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the lame
tn.text: This refers to people or animals that cannot walk.

tn.ref: I will make them as praise
tn.text: The full thought here is, "I will make them to be objects of praise," that is, "I will make them to be praised by others."

tn.ref: At that time I will lead you; at that time I will gather you together
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing and imply that Yahweh will bring the exiled people back to their homeland. AT: "At that time I will gather you together and lead you home." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
